ease-in-out

The animation-direction property specifies whether an animation should be played forwards, backwards or in alternate cycles. The following example uses the value "alternate-reverse" to make the animation run backwards first, then forwards:


**Refresh page to repeat animation transition**



Specify the fill-mode For an Animation

(CSS animations do not affect an element before the first keyframe is played or after the last keyframe is played. The animation-fill-mode property can override this behavior)


(The animation-fill-mode property specifies a style for the target element when the animation is not playing (before it starts, after it ends, or both))


(The animation-fill-mode property can have the following values)

  • none - Default value. Animation will not apply any styles to the element before or after it is executing
  • forwards - The element will retain the style values that is set by the last keyframe (depends on animation-direction and animation-iteration-count)
  • backwards - The element will get the style values that is set by the first keyframe (depends on animation-direction), and retain this during the animation-delay period
  • both - The animation will follow the rules for both forwards and backwards, extending the animation properties in both directions

(The following example lets the <div> element retain the style values from the last keyframe when the animation ends)


Example: CSS source code

div {

width: 100px;

height: 100px;

background: red;

position: relative;

animation-name: animationFillFowards;

animation-duration: 3s;

animation-fill-mode: forwards;

}


@keyframes animationFillForwards {

from {top: 0px;}

to {top: 200px; background-color: blue;}

}


Example: HTML source code

<h1>CSS Animation</h1>


<p>Let the div element retain the style values set by the last keyframe when the animation ends:</p>


<div></div>

CSS Animation


Let the div element retain the style values set by the last keyframe when the animation ends:



**Refresh page to repeat animation transition**


(The following example lets the <div> element get the style values set by the first keyframe before the animation starts (during the animation-delay period))


Example: CSS source code

div {

width: 100px;

height: 100px;

background: red;

position: relative;

animation-name: animationFillBackwards;

animation-duration: 3s;

animation-delay: 2s;

animation-fill-mode: forwards;

}


@keyframes animationFillBackwards {

from {top: 0px; background-color: yellow;}

to {top: 200px;}

}


Example: HTML source code

<div></div>

CSS Animation


Let the div element get the style values set by the first keyframe before the animation starts (during the animation-delay period):



**Refresh page to repeat animation transition**


(The following example lets the <div> element get the style values set by the first keyframe before the animation starts, and retain the style values from the last keyframe when the animation ends)


Example: CSS source code

div {

width: 100px;

height: 100px;

background: red;

position: relative;

animation-name: animationFillBoth;

animation-duration: 3s;

animation-delay: 2s;

animation-fill-mode: both;

}


@keyframes animationFillBoth {

from {top: 0px; background-color: yellow;}

to {top: 200px; 0px; background-color: blue;}

}

CSS Animation


Let the div element get the style values set by the first keyframe before the animation starts, and retain the style values from the last keyframe when the animation ends:



**Refresh page to repeat animation transition**



Animation Shorthand Property

(This example uses six of the animation properties)


Example: CSS source code

div {

width: 100px;

height: 100px;

background: red;

position: relative;

animation-name: animationShorthand;

animation-duration: 5s;

animation-delay: 2s;

animation-timing-function: linear;

animation-iteration-count: infinite;

animation-direction: alternate;

}


@keyframes animationFillBoth {

0% {background-color: red; left: 0px; top: 0px;}

25% {background-color: yellow; left: 200px; top: 0px;}

50% {background-color: blue; left: 200px; top: 200px;}

75% {background-color: green; left: 0px; top: 200px;}

100% {background-color: red; left: 0px; top: 0px;}

}


Example: HTML source code

<h1>CSS Animation</h1>


<p>This example uses six of the animation properties:</p>


<div></div>

CSS Animation


This example uses six of the animation properties:



**Refresh page to repeat animation transition**


(The same animation effect as above can be achieved by using the shorthand animation property)


Example: CSS source code

div {

width: 100px;

height: 100px;

background: red;

position: relative;

animation: animationShorthand 5s linear 2s infinite alternate;

}


@keyframes animationShorthand {

0% {background-color: red; left: 0px; top: 0px;}

25% {background-color: yellow; left: 200px; top: 0px;}

50% {background-color: blue; left: 200px; top: 200px;}

75% {background-color: green; left: 0px; top: 200px;}

100% {background-color: red; left: 0px; top: 0px;}

}

CSS Tooltips

Basic Tooltip

(A tooltip is often used to specify extra information about something when the user moves the mouse pointer over an element)


Example: CSS source code

.tooltip {

position: relative;

display: inline-block;

border-bottom: 1px dotted black;

}


.tooltip .tooltiptext {

visibility: hidden;

width: 120px;

background-color: black;

color: #fff;

text-align: center;

border-radius: 6px;

padding: 5px 0;


/* Position the tooltip */

position: absolute;

z-index: 1;

}


.tooltip:hover .tooltiptext {

visibility: visible;

}

Tooltip Arrows

(To create an arrow that should appear from a specific side of the tooltip, add "empty" content after tooltip, with the pseudo-element class ::after together with the content property. The arrow itself is created using borders. This will make the tooltip look like a speech bubble)



Bottom Arrow


Example: CSS source code

.tooltip {

position: relative;

display: inline-block;

border-bottom: 1px dotted black;

}


.tooltip .tooltiptext {

visibility: hidden;

width: 120px;

background-color: black;

color: #fff;

text-align: center;

border-radius: 6px;

padding: 5px 0;


/* Position the tooltip */

position: absolute;

z-index: 1;

bottom: 150%;

left: 50%;

margin-left: -60px;

}


.tooltip .tooltiptext::after {

content: "";

position: absolute;

top: 100%;

left: 50%;

margin-left: -5px;

border-width: 5px;

border-style: solid;

border-color: black transparent transparent transparent;


.tooltip:hover .tooltiptext {

visibility: visible;

}


Example: HTML source code

<h1>Top Tooltip w/ Bottom Arrow</h1>


<div class="tooltip">Hover over me

<span class="tooltiptext">Tooltip text</span>

</div>

Top Tooltip w/ Bottom Arrow


Hover over me Tooltip text

Fade in Tooltips (Animation)

(If you want to fade in the tooltip text when it is about to be visible, you can use the CSS transition property together with the opacity property, and go from being completely invisible to 100% visible)


Example: CSS source code

.tooltip {

position: relative;

display: inline-block;

border-bottom: 1px dotted black;

}


.tooltip .tooltiptext {

visibility: hidden;

width: 120px;

background-color: black;

color: #fff;

text-align: center;

border-radius: 6px;

padding: 5px 0;


/* Position the tooltip */

position: absolute;

z-index: 1;

bottom: 100%;

left: 50%;

margin-left: -60px;

opacity: 0;

transition: opacity 1s;

}


.tooltip:hover .tooltiptext {

visibility: visible;

opacity: 1;

}


Example: HTML source code

<h2>Fade in Tooltip on Hover</h2>


<p>When you move the mouse over the text below, the tooltip text will fade in and take 1 second to go from completely invisible to visible.</p>


<div class="tooltip">Hover over me

<span class="tooltiptext">Tooltip text</span>

</div>

}

height: auto;

opacity: 0.3;

}

top: 8px;

left: 16px;

font-size: 18px;

}


.imageTextTopRight {

position: absolute;

top: 8px;

right: 16px;

font-size: 18px;

}


.imageTextBottomLeft {

position: absolute;

bottom: 8px;

left: 16px;

font-size: 18px;

}


.imageTextBottomRight {

position: absolute;

bottom: 8px;

right: 16px;

font-size: 18px;

}


.imageTextCenter {

position: absolute;

top: 50%;

left: 50%;

font-size: 18px;

}

Image Filters

(The CSS filter property adds visual effects (like blur and saturation) to an element)


Example: CSS source code

.imageFilters {

width: 33%;

height: auto;

float: left;

max-width: 235px;

}


.imageBlur {filter: blur(4px);}

.imageBrightness {filter: brightness(250%);}

.imageContrast {filter: contrast(180%);}

.imageGrayscale {filter: grayscale(100%);}

.imgHueRotate {filter: hue-rotate(180deg);}

.imageInvert {filter: invert(100%);}

.imageOpacity {filter: opacity(50%);}

.imageSaturate {filter: saturate(7);}

.imageSepia {filter: sepia(100%);}

.imageShadow {filter: drop-shadow(8px 8px 10px green);}

Image Hover Overlay

(Fade In Text)


Example: CSS source code

.imageOverlayContainer {

position: relative;

width: 50%;

}


.imageOverlayImage {

display: block;

width: 100%;

height: auto;

}


.imageOverlayOverlay {

position: absolute;

top: 0;

bottom: 0;

left: 0;

right: 0;

height: 100%;

width: 100%;

opacity: 0;

transition: .5s ease;

background-color: #008cba;

}


.imageOverlayContainer:hover .imageOverlayOverlay {

opacity: 1;

}


.imageOverlayText {

color: white;

font-size: 20px;

position: absolute;

top: 50%;

left: 50%;

transform: translate(-50%, -50%);

-ms-transform: translate(-50%, -50%);

}


Example: HTML source code

<h2>Fade in Overlay</h2>


<div class="imageOverlayContainer">

<img src="media/img/kyle.jpg" alt="Kyle" class="imageOverlayImage">

<div class="imageOverlayOverlay">

<div class="imageOverlayText">Hello World</div>

</div>

</div>



(Fade in a Box)

.imageOverlayContainer2 {

position: relative;

width: 50%;

}


.imageOverlayImage2 {

display: block;

width: 100%;

height: auto;

transition: .5s ease;

backface-visibility: hidden;

}


.imageOverlayMiddle2 {

transition: .5 ease;

opacity: 0;

position: absolute;

top: 50%;

left: 50%;

transform: translate(-50%, -50%);

-ms-transform: translate(-50%, -50%);

}


.imageOverlayContainer2:hover .imageOverlayImage2 {

opacity: 0.3;

}


.imageOverlayContainer2:hover .imageOverlayMiddle2 {

opacity: 1;

}


.imageOverlayText2 {

background-color: #4caf50;

color: white;

font-size: 16px;

padding: 16px 32px;

}

}

Responsive Image Gallery

(CSS can be used to create image galleries. This example use media queries to re-arrange the images on different screen sizes. Resize the browser window to see the effect)


Example: CSS source code

* {

box-sizing: border-box;

}


.responsiveImageGallery {

border: 1px solid #ccc;

}


.responsiveImageGallery:hover {

border: 1px solid #777;

}


.responsiveImageGallery .responsiveImageGalleryImg {

width: 100%;

height: auto;

}


.responsiveImageGalleryDesc {

padding: 15px;

text-align: center;

}


.responsiveImageGalleryResponsive {

padding: 0 6px;

float: left;

width: 24.99999%;

}


@media only screen and (max-width: 700px) {

.responsiveImageGalleryResponsive {

width: 49.99999%;

margin: 6px 0;

}

}


@media only screen and (max-width: 500px) {

.responsiveImageGalleryResponsive {

width: 100%;

}

}


.responsiveImageGalleryClearfix:after {

content: "";

display: table;

clear: both;

}

CSS Image Reflection

(The box-reflect property is used to create an image reflection)

(The value of the box-reflect property can be: below, above, left, or right)



Reflection Below


Example: CSS source code

img {

-webkit-box-reflect: below;

}


Example: HTML source code

<h1>CSS Image Reflection</h1>


<p>Show the reflection below the image:</p>


<img src="media/img/tesla.jpeg">

CSS Image Reflection


Show the reflection below the image:




Reflection Right


Example: CSS source code

img {

-webkit-box-reflect: right;

}


Example: HTML source code

<h1>CSS Image Reflection</h1>


<p>Show the reflection right of the image:</p>


<img src="media/img/tesla.jpeg">

CSS Image Reflection


Show the reflection right of the image:




CSS Reflection Offset

(To specify the gap between the image and the reflection, add the size of the gap to the box-reflect property)


Example: CSS source code

img {

-webkit-box-reflect: below 20px;

}


Example: HTML source code

<h1>CSS Image Reflection</h1>


<p>Show the reflection below the image, with a 20 pixels offset:</p>


<img src="media/img/tesla.jpeg">

CSS Image Reflection


Show the reflection below the image, with a 20 pixels offset:




CSS Reflection With Gradient

(We can also create a fade-out effect on the reflection)


Example: CSS source code

img {

-webkit-box-reflect: below 0px linear-gradient(to bottom, rgba(0,0,0,0.0), rgba(0,0,0,0.4));

}


Example: HTML source code

<h1>CSS Image Reflection</h1>


<p>Show the reflection with gradient (to make a fade-out effect):</p>


<img src="media/img/tesla.jpeg">

CSS object-fit

The CSS object-fit property is used to specify how an <img> or <video> should be resized to fit its container



The CSS object-fit Property

(This property tells the content to fill the container in a variety of ways; such as "preserve that aspect ratio" or "stretch up and take up as much space as possible")


(Here is where the object-fit property comes in. The object-fit property can take one of the following values)


  • - This is default. The image is resized to fill the given dimension. If necessary, the image will be stretched or squished to fit
  • - The image keeps its aspect ratio, but is resized to fit within the given dimension
  • - The image keeps its aspect ratio and fills the given dimension. The image will be clipped to fit
  • - The image is not resized
  • - the image is scaled down to the smallest version of none or contain


Using object-fit: cover;

(If we use object-fit: cover; the image keeps its aspect ratio and fills the given dimension. The image will be clipped to fit)


Example: CSS source code

img {

width: 200px;

height: 300px;

object-fit: cover;

}


Example: HTML source code

<h2>Using object-fit: cover;</h2>


<img src="media/img/tesla.jpeg" alt="Tesla" width="400" height="300">

Using object-fit: cover;




Using object-fit: contain;

(If we use object-fit: contain; the image keeps its aspect ratio, but is resized to fit within the given dimension)


Example: CSS source code

img {

width: 200px;

height: 300px;

object-fit: contain;

}


Example: HTML source code

<h2>Using object-fit: contain;</h2>


<img src="media/img/tesla.jpeg" alt="Tesla" width="400" height="300">

Using object-fit: contain;




Using object-fit: fill;

(If we use object-fit: fill; the image is resized to fill the given dimension. If necessary, the image will be stretched or squished to fit)


Example: CSS source code

img {

width: 200px;

height: 300px;

object-fit: fill;

}


Example: HTML source code

<h2>Using object-fit: fill;</h2>


<img src="media/img/tesla.jpeg" alt="Tesla" width="400" height="300">

Using object-fit: fill;




Using object-fit: none;

(If we use object-fit: none; the image is not resized)


Example: CSS source code

img {

width: 200px;

height: 300px;

object-fit: none;

}


Example: HTML source code

<h2>Using object-fit: none;</h2>


<img src="media/img/tesla.jpeg" alt="Tesla" width="400" height="300">

Using object-fit: none;




Using object-fit: scale-down;

(If we use object-fit: scale-down; the image is scaled down to the smallest version of none or contain


Example: CSS source code

img {

width: 200px;

height: 300px;

object-fit: scale-down;

}


Example: HTML source code

<h2>Using object-fit: scale-down;</h2>


<img src="media/img/tesla.jpeg" alt="Tesla" width="400" height="300">

Using object-fit: scale-down;


CSS object-position

(The CSS object-position property is used to specify how an <img> or <video> should be positioned within its container)

Using the object-position Property

(Let's say that the part of the image that is shown, is not positioned as we want)

(To position the image, we will use the object-position property)


Example: CSS source code

img {

width: 200px;

height: 300px;

object-fit: cover;

object-position: 80% 100%;

}


Example: HTML source code

<h2>Using object-position</h2>


<p>Here we will use the object-position property to position the image so that the great old building is in center:</p>


<img src="media/img/tesla.jpeg" alt="Tesla" width="400" height="300">

Using object-fit: scale-down;


Here we will use the object-position property to position the image so that the great old building is in center:


CSS Masking

With CSS masking you create a mask layer to place over an element to partially or fully hide portions of the element



The CSS mask-image Property

(The CSS mask-image property specifies a mask layer image)

(The mask layer image can be a PNG image, an SVG image, a CSS gradient, or an SVG <mask> element)



Use an Image as the Mask Layer

(To use a PNG or an SVG image as the mask layer, use a url() value to pass in the mask layer image)

(The mask image needs to have a transparent or semi-transparent area. Black indicates fully transparent)


Example: CSS source code

.mask1 {

-webkit-mask-image: url(w3logo.png);

mask-image: url(w3logo.png);

-webkit-mask-repeat: no-repeat;

mask-repeat: no-repeat;

}


Example: HTML source code

<h1>The mask-image Property</h1>


<div class="mask1">

<img src="media/img/soft_background_color.jpeg" alt="Soft Background Color" width="600" height="400">

</div>







Example: CSS source code

.mask2 {

-webkit-mask-image: url(w3logo.png);

mask-image: url(w3logo.png);

-webkit-mask-repeat: no-repeat;

mask-repeat: repeat;

}


Example: HTML source code

<h1>The mask-image Property</h1>


<div class="mask2">

<img src="media/img/soft_background_color.jpeg" alt="Soft Background Color" width="600" height="400">

</div>

}

Disabled Buttons

(Use the opacity property to add transparency to a button (creates a "disabled" look))

(You can also add the cursor property with a value of "not-allowed", which will display a "no parking sign" when you mouse over the button)


Example: CSS source code

.buttonsBasic {

background-color: #04aa6d;

border: none;

color: white;

padding: 15px 32px;

text-align: center;

text-decoration: none;

display: inline-block;

font-size: 16px;

margin: 4px 2px;

cursor: pointer;

}


.disabled {

opacity: 0.6;

cursor: not-allowed;

}


Example: HTML source code

<h2>Disabled Button</h2>


<p>Use the opacity property to add some transparency to a button (make it look disabled):</p>


<button class="buttonsBasic">Normal Button</button>

<button class="buttonsBasic disabled">Disabled Button</button>

Disabled Button


Use the opacity property to add some transparency to a button (make it look disabled):




Button Width

(By default, the size of the button is determined by its text content (as wide as its content). Use the width property to change the width of a button)


Example: CSS source code

.buttonsBasic {

background-color: #04aa6d;

border: none;

color: white;

padding: 15px 32px;

text-align: center;

text-decoration: none;

display: inline-block;

font-size: 16px;

margin: 4px 2px;

cursor: pointer;

}


.buttonWidth1 {

width: 250px;

}


.buttonWidth2 {

width: 50%;

}


.buttoWidth3 {

width: 100%;

}


Example: HTML source code

<h2>Set Button Widths</h2>


<p>Use the width property to change the width of the button:</p>


<button class="buttonsBasic buttonWidth1">250px</button><br>

<button class="buttonsBasic buttonWidth2">50%</button><br>

<button class="buttonsBasic buttonWidth3">100%</button>


<p><strong>Tip:</strong>Use pixels if you want to set a fixed width and use percent for responsive
buttons (e.g. 50% of its parent element). Resize the browser window to see the effect.</p>

Set Button Widths


Use the width property to change the width of the button:





Tip: Use pixels if you want to set a fixed width and use percent for responsive buttons (e.g. 50% of its parent element). Resize the browser window to see the effect.



Button Groups

(Remove margins and add float:left to each button to create a button group)


Example: CSS source code

.buttonsBasic .btn-group {

background-color: #04aa6d;

border: none;

color: white;

padding: 15px 32px;

text-align: center;

text-decoration: none;

display: inline-block;

font-size: 16px;

float: left;

cursor: pointer;

}


.btn-group .buttonsBasic:hover {

background-color: #3e8e41;

}


Example: HTML source code

<h2>Button Groups</h2>


<p>Remove margins and float the buttons to create a button group:</p>


<div class="btn-group">

<button class="buttonsBasic">Button</button><br>

<button class="buttonsBasic">Button</button><br>

<button class="buttonsBasic">Button</button><br>

<button class="buttonsBasic">Button</button><br>

</div>


<p><br>Remember to clear floats after, or else will this p element also float next to the buttons.</p>

Button Groups


Remove margins and float the buttons to create a button group:




Remember to clear floats after, or else will this p element also float next to the buttons.



Bordered Button Group

(Use the border property to create a bordered button group)


Example: CSS source code

.buttonsBasic .btn-group {

background-color: #04aa6d;

border: 1px solid green;

color: white;

padding: 15px 32px;

text-align: center;

text-decoration: none;

display: inline-block;

font-size: 16px;

float: left;

cursor: pointer;

}


.btn-group .buttonsBasic:hover {

background-color: #3e8e41;

}


.btn-group .buttonsBasic:not(:last-child) {

border-right: none;

}


Example: HTML source code

<h2>Bordered Button Group</h2>


<p>Add borders to create a bordered button group:</p>


<div class="btn-group">

<button class="buttonsBasic">Button</button><br>

<button class="buttonsBasic">Button</button><br>

<button class="buttonsBasic">Button</button><br>

<button class="buttonsBasic">Button</button><br>

</div>


<p><br>Remember to clear floats after, or else will this p element also float next to the buttons.</p>

Bordered Button Group


Add borders to create a bordered button group:




Remember to clear floats after, or else will this p element also float next to the buttons.



Vertical Button Group

(Use display:block instead of float:left to group the buttons below each other, instead of side by side)


Example: CSS source code

.buttonsBasic .btn-group {

background-color: #04aa6d;

border: 1px solid green;

color: white;

padding: 15px 32px;

text-align: center;

text-decoration: none;

display: block;

width: 150px;

cursor: pointer;

}


.btn-group .buttonsBasic:hover {

background-color: #3e8e41;

}


.btn-group .buttonsBasic:not(:last-child) {

border-bottom: none;

}


Example: HTML source code

<h2>Vertical Button Group</h2>


<div class="btn-group">

<button class="buttonsBasic">Button</button><br>

<button class="buttonsBasic">Button</button><br>

<button class="buttonsBasic">Button</button><br>

<button class="buttonsBasic">Button</button><br>

</div>

Vertical Button Group




Button on Image


Example: CSS source code

.btnOnImageContainer {

position: relative;

width: 100%;

max-width: 400px;

}


.btnOnImageContainer .btnOnImageImage {

width: 100%;

height: auto;

}


.btnOnImageContainer .btnOnImageBtn {

position: absolute;

top: 50%;

left: 50%;

transform: translate(-50%, -50%);

-ms-transform: translate(-50%, -50%);

background-color: #f1f1f1;

color: black;

font-size: 16px;

padding: 16px 30px;

border: none;

cursor: pointer;

border-radius: 5px;

text-align: center;

}


.btnOnImageContainer .btnOnImageBtn:hover {

background-color: black;

color: white;

}


Example: HTML source code

<h2>Button on Image</h2>


<p>Add a button on an image:</p>


<div class="btnOnImageContainer">

<img src="media/img/tesla.jpeg"> alt="Tesla" style="width:100%" class="btnOnImageImage">

<button class="btnOnImageBtn">Button</button><br>

</div>

Animated Buttons


Example: CSS source code

.btnAnimated {

display: inline-block;

border-radius: 4px;

background-color: #f4511e;

border: none;

color: #ffffff;

text-align: center;

font-size: 28px;

padding: 20px;

width: 200px;

transition: all 0.5s;

cursor: pointer;

margin: 5px;

}


.btnAnimated .btnAnimatedSpan {

cursor: pointer;

display: inline-block;

position: relative;

transition: 0.5s;

}


.btnAnimated .btnAnimatedSpan:after {

content: '\00bb';

position: absolute;

opacity: 0;

top: 0;

right: -20px;

transition: 0.5s;

}


.btnAnimated:hover .btnAnimatedSpan {

padding-right: 25px;

}


.btnAnimated:hover .btnAnimatedSpan:after {

opacity: 1;

right: 0;

}


Example: HTML source code

<h2>Animated Button</h2>


<button class="btnAnimated" style="vertical-align: middle;">< span>Hover</span>< /button>

Animated Button



Animated Button - "Pressed Effect"


Example: CSS source code

.btnAnimated2 {

display: inline-block;

padding: 15px 25px;

font-size: 24px;

cursor: pointer;

text-align: center;

text-decoration: none;

outline: none;

color: #ffffff;

background-color: #04aa6d;

border: none;

border-radius: 15px;

box-shadow: 0 9px #999;

}


.btnAnimated2:hover {

background-color: #3e8e41;

}


.btnAnimated2:active {

background-color: #3e8e41;

box-shadow: 0 5px #666;

transform: translateY(4px);

}


Example: HTML source code

<h2>Animated Button - "Pressed Effect"</h2>


<button class="btnAnimated2">Click Me</button>

Animated Button - "Pressed Effect"

}

Animated Button - Ripple Effect


Example: CSS source code

.btnAnimated4 {

position: relative;

background-color: #04aa6d;

border: none;

font-size: 28px;

color: #ffffff;

padding: 20px;

width: 200px;

text-align: center;

transition-duration: 0.4s;

text-decoration: none;

overflow: hidden;

cursor: pointer;

}


.btnAnimated4:after {

content: "";

background: #f1f1f1;

display: block;

position: absolute;

padding-top: 300%;

padding-left: 350%;

margin-left: -20px !important;

margin-top: -120%;

opacity: 0;

transition: all 0.8s;


.btnAnimated4:active:after {

padding: 0;

margin: 0;

opacity: 1;

transition: 0s;


Example: HTML source code

CSS Pagination

Simple Pagination


(If you have a website with lots of pages, you may wish to add some sort of pagination to each page)


Example: CSS source code

.cssPagination {

display: inline-block;

}


.cssPagination a {

color: black;

float: left;

padding: 8px 16px;

text-decoration: none;

}


Example: HTML source code

<h2>Simple Pagination</h2>


<div class="cssPagination">

<a href="#">&laquo;</a>

<a href="#">1</a>

<a href="#">2</a>

<a href="#">3</a>

<a href="#">4</a>

<a href="#">5</a>

<a href="#">6</a>

<a href="#">&raquo;</a>

</div>

Simple Pagination


« 1 2 3 4 5 6 »

Active and Hoverable Pagination

(Highlight the current page with an .active class, and use the :hover selector to change the color of each page link when moving the mouse over them)


Example: CSS source code

.cssPagination {

display: inline-block;

}


.cssPagination a {

color: black;

float: left;

padding: 8px 16px;

text-decoration: none;

}


.cssPagination a:active {

background-color: #4caf50;

color: white;

}


.cssPagination a:hover:not(.active) {

background-color: #dddddd;

}


Example: HTML source code

<h2>Active and Hoverable Pagination</h2>


<p>Move the mouse over the numbers.</p>


<div class="cssPagination2">

<a href="#">&laquo;</a>

<a href="#">1</a>

<a class="active" href="#">2</a>

<a href="#">3</a>

<a href="#">4</a>

<a href="#">5</a>

<a href="#">6</a>

<a href="#">&raquo;</a>

</div>

Active and Hoverable Pagination

Rounded Active and Hoverable Buttons

(Add the border-radius property if you want a rounded "active" and "hover" button)


Example: CSS source code

.cssPagination {

display: inline-block;

}


.cssPagination a {

color: black;

float: left;

padding: 8px 16px;

text-decoration: none;

}


.cssPagination a:active {

background-color: #4caf50;

color: white;

border-radius: 5px;

}


.cssPagination a:hover:not(.active) {

background-color: #dddddd;

border-radius: 5px;

}


Example: HTML source code

<a href="#">1</a>

<a href="#">4</a>

<a href="#">5</a>

<a href="#">6</a>

<a href="#">&raquo;</a>

</div>

Hoverable Transition Effect

(Add the transition property to the page links to create a transition effect on hover)


Example: CSS source code

.cssPagination {

display: inline-block;

}


.cssPagination a {

color: black;

float: left;

padding: 8px 16px;

text-decoration: none;

transition: .3s;

}


.cssPagination a:active {

background-color: #4caf50;

color: white;

}


.cssPagination a:hover:not(.active) {

background-color: #dddddd;

}


Example: HTML source code

<h2>Transition Effect on Hover</h2>


<p>Move the mouse over the numbers.</p>


<div class="cssPagination">

<a href="#">&laquo;</a>

<a href="#">1</a>

<a class="active" href="#">2</a>

<a href="#">3</a>

<a href="#">4</a>

<a href="#">5</a>

<a href="#">6</a>

<a href="#">&raquo;</a>

</div>

Bordered Pagination

(Use the border property to add borders to the pagination)


Example: CSS source code

.cssPagination {

display: inline-block;

}


.cssPagination a {

color: black;

float: left;

padding: 8px 16px;

text-decoration: none;

transition: .3s;

border: 1px solid black;

}


.cssPagination a:active {

background-color: #4caf50;

color: white;

border: 1px solid black;

}


.cssPagination a:hover:not(.active) {

background-color: #dddddd;

}


Example: HTML source code

<h2>Pagination with Borders</h2>


<div class="cssPagination">

<a href="#">&laquo;</a>

<a href="#">1</a>

<a class="active" href="#">2</a>

<a href="#">3</a>

<a href="#">4</a>

<a href="#">5</a>

<a href="#">6</a>

<a href="#">&raquo;</a>

</div>
